Award.AbstractNarration:
The Qualitative Data Repository (QDR) launched in January 2014 at Syracuse University. QDR is the first general purpose venue in the United States for storing and sharing digital data generated or collected through qualitative and multi-method research in the social sciences. The repository curates, manages, preserves, and shares digital data, and also develops and disseminates standards and techniques for engaging in these practices. It also vigorously promotes the effective management, sharing, and reuse of qualitative data, and engagement in research transparency.

QDR has made excellent progress, and will continue to advance, along five dimensions: (1) governance - developing internal management structures and policies and engaging with the broader data-management community; (2) technical capacity - securing the hardware to house, and developing the software to enable the deposit, indexing, search, and download of qualitative data; (3) content - soliciting and curating qualitative data projects for secondary analysis, to increase research transparency, and to enhance teaching; (4) ideational frameworks - developing the intellectual framework for, a language to talk about, techniques and practices to engage in, and guidance to facilitate data sharing and transparency in qualitative research; and (5) promulgation and persuasion - stimulating and participating in debate and dialogue to generate standards for sharing qualitative data, conducting secondary data analysis, evaluating empirical research, and teaching with data, and encouraging and teaching people to do so.

Institutionalized repositories such as QDR produce multi-faceted benefits. First, they allow shared data to be more usable, discoverable, meaningful, citable, secure, durable, and broadly accessible, and they increase data visibility. Second, they also reduce data-collection redundancy, allow data to accumulate, and allow for secondary analysis, encouraging comparative study and new research. Third, by offering a platform for data-sharing, such repositories encourage transparent research; such research can be evaluated and replicated, encouraging methodological rigor and facilitating the continued development of research methods.

The value QDR adds on each of these fronts is particularly important given the weak tradition of sharing the rich and heterogeneous data that qualitative social scientists generate, often through considerable effort. QDR is staffed by scholars with experience curating qualitative data, and offers a broad range of guidance, educational resources, and training focused on storing, sharing, and reusing such data. Qualitative political scientists are comfortable sharing their data with QDR as they perceive it to be a venue that is sympathetic to the goals and techniques of their research tradition.

QDR enhances the data-management infrastructure in the United States, an infrastructure that underpins both research and teaching: it allows for their integration and thereby strengthens both. QDR has the potential to broaden the access of scholars from around the world to a wealth of qualitative social science data. In addition, by increasing researcher visibility, the repository encourages intellectual exchange and the formation and growth of epistemic communities, and serves as a platform for research networks and partnerships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Qualitative Data Repository (QDR) curates, stores, preserves, publishes, and enables the download of digital data used in qualitative and multi-method social inquiry.  The repository also develops and publicizes common standards and methodologically informed practices for managing, sharing, citing, and reusing qualitative data.  

Four beliefs underpin QDR's mission: 

• Data that can be shared and reused should be. QDR recognizes that creating social science data takes considerable effort, expertise, and resources. Given that outlay, data that are only used once are underused. QDR’s infrastructure enables scholars to engage in secondary analysis of data and ensures funders maximum return on their investment. 

• Evidence-based claims in published research should be made transparently. QDR’s activities are in line with the increasing attention social science is paying to making research more open and thus more rigorous and evaluable.

• Rigorous social science requires common understandings of research methods. By facilitating research transparency, QDR contributes to research communities’ efforts to develop and promulgate consensual rules and guidance for producing research findings.

• Teaching (and especially instruction on methods) is enriched by the use of well-documented data. QDR’s approach to pedagogical data is based on the widely held belief that students internalize research methods more quickly and completely when they use them. This is a standard approach in statistics, where texts commonly include links to “pedagogical data”—common, stylized data specifically prepared for teaching purposes—that maximize student engagement with the methods being taught. The data QDR publishes facilitate the adoption of this hands-on approach in qualitative methods training.

During the grant period, QDR made considerable progress in several areas.

First, QDR continued to grow its data holdings. These are available to researchers across the United States and around the world, for the analytic, transparency-related, and pedagogical purposes noted above. These data’s availability also encourage scholarly interactions and facilitate the creation of epistemic communities, networks and partnerships.

With regard to technology, QDR started to update its initial repository prototype with the open-source repository software Dataverse. This change reduces QDR’s technical debt, augments functionality, and maximizes the interoperability of the repository’s holdings. As the Dataverse platform was primarily built for quantitative data, in conjunction with the Dataverse development community, QDR began to design features and functionality that will allow Dataverse to capture the strengths of qualitative data. QDR also prepared to migrate the host of its hardware infrastructure from a single set of servers provisioned by Syracuse University to a cluster of high-performance servers and virtual private networks (VPNs) hosted by Amazon Web Services (AWS).

In addition, in collaboration with a software firm, QDR developed Annotation for Transparent Inquiry (ATI), a new approach for rendering narrative qualitative research more rigorous and persuasive. In much qualitative work, individual pieces or small groups of data are deployed, and analysis and conclusions densely woven, throughout a published text. Openness thus requires that data (and attendant information about their generation, analysis, and use) be tightly integrated across the span of publications. Yet those data are also expected to be FAIR (findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable). Building on “active citation” (an earlier approach to achieving transparency in qualitative research pioneered by Andrew Moravcsik), ATI addresses this challenge by empowering scholars to annotate their scholarship using “open annotation” technology. This technology allows for the generation, sharing, and discovery of digital annotations across the web. ATI also solves the structural problem that making qualitative research transparent represents: data repositories, rather than publishers, bear the cost and responsibility of curating (e.g., providing persistent identifiers such as DOIs and rich metadata), hosting, and preserving FAIR data.   In addition, QDR made further progress on its Institutional Review Board initiative, which addresses the fundamental tensions that can arise between sharing the data produced by human participants research, and protecting human participants. Such tensions can complicate transparency efforts – yet to date there has been little interaction between two communities best positioned to work together toward ameliorating those tensions:  the IRB and data services communities. In an effort to catalyze conversation, and in view of the elaboration of the new Common Rule (or Federal Policy for the Protection of Human Subjects), QDR has convened relevant stakeholders (e.g., university leadership, IRB personnel, and data repository representatives) in a series of workshops. 

During the grant period, QDR also engaged in multiple forms of outreach to the social sciences and data services communities including publishing guidance materials on our web site, organizing workshops, teaching, attending conferences and other events, and publishing scholarly work. Our institutional collaboration has aided in identifying and developing strategies to address key obstacles and challenges to sharing qualitative data.

QDR has also created robust administrative arrangements that foster stability and efficiency, enlisted well-qualified specialists to serve multi-year terms on our two advisory boards, and continued to develop a business model with institutional membership as its cornerstone.
